metadata.title: Convert Stone to Kilograms – Weight Converter
metadata.description: Convert weight from stone (st) to kilograms (kg) using the internationally defined relationship between the pound and the kilogram.

introduction: This stone to kilograms converter lets you convert body weight, building materials, and other loads from stone (st) to kilograms (kg) using the internationally agreed definitions of the pound and the kilogram.

The stone is still commonly used in the United Kingdom and Ireland for body weight and some construction contexts, while the kilogram is the SI base unit of mass used in engineering, science, and most regulatory and technical documentation worldwide.
methodology: This converter is based on the exact definition of the international avoirdupois pound. Since 1959, English-speaking nations have agreed that 1 pound (lb) is exactly equal to 0.45359237 kilograms. A stone is defined as exactly 14 pounds in the avoirdupois system.

Using these definitions, 1 stone is exactly equal to 14 × 0.45359237 kilograms, which gives 1 stone = 6.35029318 kilograms. This factor is exact, so there is no rounding ambiguity in the underlying physics or metrology; any rounding happens only when results are displayed for practical use.

Because the kilogram is the SI base unit of mass as maintained by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, expressing weights in kilograms improves comparability across disciplines, including engineering design, structural load calculations, occupational safety limits, and clinical or nutritional assessments.

In practical use, engineers, architects, and health professionals typically round stone to kilogram conversions to an appropriate number of decimal places depending on context. For example, body weight may be reported to one decimal place in kilograms, while bulk construction materials or large loads may be rounded to the nearest kilogram for inventory and logistics purposes.

faqs.question: How many kilograms are in one stone?
faqs.answer: One stone is exactly 6.35029318 kilograms. This comes from the definition of the stone as 14 pounds and the international definition of 1 pound as exactly 0.45359237 kilograms.

faqs.question: Why is the conversion from stone to kilograms considered exact?
faqs.answer: The conversion is exact because both links in the chain are defined by international agreement: 1 stone is defined as exactly 14 avoirdupois pounds, and 1 pound is defined as exactly 0.45359237 kilograms. Multiplying these two exact values gives 1 stone = 6.35029318 kilograms with no experimental uncertainty.

faqs.question: Where is stone still used instead of kilograms?
faqs.answer: Stone is mainly used in the United Kingdom and Ireland for describing personal body weight and occasionally in informal contexts for loads or materials. In most engineering, scientific, and regulatory documents, mass and weight are expressed in kilograms in line with SI recommendations.

faqs.question: How should I round stone to kilogram conversions for professional work?
faqs.answer: For engineering, construction, and safety calculations, rounding practices should follow your organization's technical standards or applicable codes. A common approach is to keep at least three significant figures for intermediate calculations and then round final values to the precision appropriate for the decision being made, for example to the nearest 0.1 kg for body weight or to the nearest kilogram for large loads.

faqs.question: Is this converter suitable for health, fitness, and clinical use?
faqs.answer: Yes, as long as you interpret the results within the precision limits required for your application. The conversion factor is based on international SI and metrology standards, which are also used in clinical, nutritional, and public health guidance. For diagnosis or treatment decisions, always follow local clinical protocols and use calibrated equipment where required.

faqs.question: Can I convert kilograms back to stone using the same relationship?
faqs.answer: Yes. To convert kilograms to stone, divide the mass in kilograms by 6.35029318. Many professionals also express the result as stone and pounds, but the underlying relationship with kilograms remains based on the same exact factor.

examples: A person weighing 11 stone has a mass of 11 × 6.35029318 ≈ 69.85 kilograms, often rounded to 69.9 kg for health and fitness records.
A load of 3 stone corresponds to 3 × 6.35029318 ≈ 19.05 kilograms, which may be rounded to 19.1 kg for reporting or inventory purposes.
If a material specification lists a limit of 1.5 stone, the equivalent SI value is 1.5 × 6.35029318 ≈ 9.53 kilograms.
summary: This converter uses the exact international definitions of the pound and the stone to provide precise stone to kilogram conversions. By working in kilograms, you align with SI practice used in engineering, science, and regulatory documents, while still accommodating users who think in stone for everyday or regional reasons.
glossary: Stone (st): A traditional unit of mass in the avoirdupois system, defined as exactly 14 pounds. Commonly used for body weight in the United Kingdom and Ireland.
Pound (lb): The international avoirdupois pound is a unit of mass defined as exactly 0.45359237 kilograms under the 1959 international yard and pound agreement.
Kilogram (kg): The SI base unit of mass, defined in terms of the Planck constant and maintained by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures (BIPM).
